thread.title: Specialties from barbecue to oysters enhance local flavor
thread.title_full: Specialties from barbecue to oysters enhance local flavor

title: Specialties from barbecue to oysters enhance local flavor
text:
Specialties from barbecue to oysters enhance local flavor Travel 
Powered by Local Corporation By Lynn O'Rourke Hayes THE DALLAS MORNING NEWS • Sunday August 30, 2015 5:00 AM 
Culinary traditions often enrich a destination. Help your family develop a taste for travel with local specialties from across the country. 
Here are five ideas to consider. 
• Memphis, Tenn. A visit to this Southern gem might well include a stop at Graceland, the home of Elvis Presley. The Memphis Flash was well-known for his passion for creative comfort food. 
Not far from his legendary digs, you’ll find the Arcade Restaurant, a 1950s-style, family-owned diner that serves Elvis favorites such as his go-to sandwich: fried peanut butter and banana on Texas toast. 
Visit arcaderestaurant.com and www.memphistravel.com 
• Phoenix-Scottsdale, Ariz. There are plenty of reasons you’ll need to hydrate in the Valley of the Sun. Since 1958, the TeePee Tap Room has been the choice of presidents and families seeking homemade Mexican food. The Mission, Barrio Queen and La Hacienda are also popular. 
Visit www.experiencescottsdale.com or www.visitphoenix.com 
• Kansas City, Mo. You won’t want to visit this Midwestern town without savoring a dry-rubbed, slow-smoked slab of barbecue ribs. More than 100 establishments blend a mouthwatering combination of flavors and styles, according to the Kansas City Barbecue Society. 
Among the favorites: Arthur Bryant’s, Fiorella’s Jack Stack Barbecue and Gates Bar-B-Q. 
Go to www.visitkc.com 
• The California coast. From historic Monterey through scenic seaside stretches to a tour of Hearst Castle, a trip along the coast will be one to remember. 
Hungry? Expect fresh produce, fish and small-batch ice cream. To help sort through the wealth of options, the culinary insiders at Open Table have created a summer road-trip guide to great dining from San Francisco’s Zuni Cafe to San Diego’s Bottega Americano, with plenty of savory stops in between. 
Visit blog.opentable.com or www.visitcalifornia.com 
• Rhode Island. Cultivating oysters has been a practice here since the arrival of the American Indians. During a New England adventure, learn about the recent boom in aquaculture and how oysters make their way to an icy platter in a top spot such as Hemenway’s in Providence.
